abstract.p: Letter from Brooklyn Heights Assn president Neil Chalet comments on August 16 article on opposition to construction of waterfront park in Brooklyn Heights

block.p: Your Aug. 16 news article about the controversy surrounding the proposed Brooklyn Bridge Park correctly reports that the Brooklyn Heights Association endorses the vision of a major park on our downtown waterfront. So do the associations representing the adjacent neighborhoods of Cobble Hill, Dumbo, Fort Greene and Fulton Ferry Landing.

Your Aug. 16 news article about the controversy surrounding the proposed Brooklyn Bridge Park correctly reports that the Brooklyn Heights Association endorses the vision of a major park on our downtown waterfront. So do the associations representing the adjacent neighborhoods of Cobble Hill, Dumbo, Fort Greene and Fulton Ferry Landing.

But although we disagree profoundly with those who reject the plan out of hand, we have no reason to believe that their dissent is racially motivated, as your article suggests. There may be isolated instances of such ill will, but we don't doubt that the great majority of that small minority opposing the park plan is acting out of sincere conviction. We are convinced that during the coming review process the dissenting faction will see many of its concerns allayed.
NEIL CALET President Brooklyn Heights Association Brooklyn, Aug. 16, 2000
